B000AWYOGE|5.0|This film, which cross-pollinates the psychological suspense thriller with the traditional ghost story, is not so much scary as disturbing. The plot, in brief:  Dahlia Williams (Jennifer Connelly) has separated from her husband. The two of them are involved in a tense custody battle for their daughter, five-year-old Ceci (Ariel Gade).  Forced to cut expenses to the bone, Dahlia finds a tawdry ninth floor apartment in a rent-controlled, dilapidated building on gloomy Roosevelt Island just off Manhattan. Strange events begin to occur, involving a mysterious backpack Ceci finds on the roof, whispers at night, noises from the abandoned apartment one floor above--and a leak in her front-room ceiling that keeps coming back. While Dahlia struggles to balance the demands of a new job with those of her estranged husband which now include the need to find an attorney, she has nightmares, battles migraines, and pleads with an apathetic landlord and his creepy maintenance man to fix her ceiling before it caves in. Her daughter, meanwhile, has found an \\"imaginary playmate\\" named Natasha--a name the girl couldn't possibly have invented and who, gradually, takes on a frightening reality as walls of \\"dark water\\" steadily close in on the two of them.  <br /> <br />Director Walter Salles and his team did a superb job increasing the believability of this story's supernatural elements by easing us first into a gritty background of New York realism. Doubtless many of us have dealt with landlords who were backslappers, assuring us this would be done and that would be taken care of, and then lose interest once your name is on the dotted line (and we don't even live in New York!). And there are plenty of employees more interested in their pensions or adhering to union policy than getting a job done. Or they \\"don't want to get involved.\\" Nothing in Dahlia's new building works right. The elevators also leak; they malfunction; the washing machines don't work. These expected features of dilapidated buildings provide a seamless transition to the story's supernatural elements.  Another atmospheric soundtrack by Angelo Badalamenti (Twin Peaks, Arlington Road) quietly enhances the all-pervasive sense of claustrophobia.  <br /> <br />The effects are superb from start to finish.  Water permeates everything.  Dripping water, puddling water, brackish standing water, dirty water spurting from nasty-rusty faucets and out of sinks, not to mention pouring down the walls in one of Dahlia's nightmares. Add to this the constant rain in scene after scene. Because there is so much variety, the use of water never seems overdone, and is balanced by plenty of other effective techniques. Among the best of these is the distinctly uncomfortable metallic whine and heart-like thumping that accompanies Dahlia's migraines--very suggestive of what the character is going through. The camera work is quite good as well. I don't believe I've seen a ceiling leak's POV before.  <br /> <br />The acting, finally, is brilliant.  Jennifer Connelly is at her best in a difficult role--and has anyone noticed how young Ariel Gade (perhaps better known to some viewers as Rose, from last year's TV series Invasion) is turning into one of the finest child actresses around? Her performance here exhibits a level of professionalism far in advance of her years (she was born in 1997!). The dynamic between her and Connelly is nearly perfect!  Their lines never seem clever or overly melodramatic, but pack just the right emotional punch--you can actually feel Dahlia's rising alarm when, courtesy of her \\"imaginary playmate,\\" Ceci knows things she can't possibly know--especially Dahlia's having been abused and rejected by her alcoholic mother. That scene sent chills down my spine. The supporting roles--by John C. Reilly as Murray the backslapping resident manager, Pete Postlethwaite as the creepy Veeck, Tim Roth as Dahlia's lawyer, Dougray Scott as her estranged husband Kyle--and finally, Camryn Manheim (Boston Legal) as Ceci's schoolteacher, mostly do what their various scenes need them to do. The only thing I found bothersome was that Dahlia's lawyer clearly lied to her about getting back to his family in the movies--not advancing the plot and making us wonder for no reason, as it turned out, whether Dahlia can trust him.  <br /> <br />In sum: Dark Water is all shifting moods and claustrophobic ambience. There's no gore, and not that much action. To my mind this sort of character-driven narrative is much more unsettling than creatures shambling around in the dark or even maniacs bearing long knives. The creatures obviously aren't real, and (most of the time) neither are the maniacs in their hockey masks. What scares us is what the ghostly antagonist represents. The \\"monster\\" in this film is a little girl who was abandoned by her parents in a ghastly mistake. Children do get abandoned in the real world. Separations and divorces do happen--all the time. People do end up struggling to survive, often under horrid living conditions, compelled to deal with others' indifference. I don't recommend this for children, and only hesitatingly recommend it for parents of children undergoing difficult separations and divorces. You know who you are. I give it five stars, though. It is a well told, brilliantly-realized bit of storytelling, with an ending that supplies a real jolt (no spoilers!). Dark Water compelled me to take a walk afterwards, and that's usually the way I measure the success of a film like this. Fortunately it wasn't raining.
B000AMJG4Y|4.0|Could have been a little better, but overall not too bad.  This was one of my favorite video games of all time.  It was nice to see the story continued.
0375423877|5.0|I absolutely love this book. Alexander McCall Smith is long overdue - he is such a change from the usual fictional writers who are out there today. Mma Ramotswe is such a great character for starters. She is kind and intelligent, and a very far cry from the more typical mystery detectives. She takes her time, and often solves cases with pure logic and common sense. It's a relief to read a book about honest, normal people, and a relief to discover that a mystery novel can be written without anybody being murdered and can still be interesting. The setting itself makes the stories astounding. Smith can describe Africa and show you there is more than third-world countries and poverty. Read this and see that not every country in Africa is riddled with war and hatred. And that not every African is uneducated and poor. Smith shows the beauty and the ugliness, and leaves me at least wanting to read more.
1594200823|4.0|This book is a well written account of the 'State of the Union' as it applies to the agricultural industry in the US. I highly recommend this book but I want to mention one unresolved point that has been bothering me. The author states that three fifths of the worlds population would not be able to survive without the use of chemical fertilizer which are created by 'fixing' nitrogen. Then he goes on to laud the biodiverse, yet nearly closed loop at Polyface farm as the model for Farming. So is his point that the other 3/5ths of the worlds population will have to die off to return to sustainable limits?  <br /> <br />Cultural traditions in China have optimized the production of rice, but they still needed to augment traditional methods with chemical fertilizers to feed the population. The bottom line is that the world has exceeded it's carrying capacity and overburdened the natural resources available on this planet. Yes technoology has allowed us to exceed that limit temporarily, but we have only pushed back the threshold.

0345349571|4.0|Tuchman's book presents a thourough, redable account of the fourteent century and its major events (the Black Death and the start of the Hundred Years' War, for starters). While a few of the details of medieval life included in the book have inevitably been superceded by more recent research, this is more than made up for by the book's many strong points.<br /><br />Tuchman's prose is clear and far from textbook-like, but without seeming to make a point of it, and her decision to follow the life of one of the more important participants in many of the century's numerous wars/battles/etc. unifies the narration much more than would be possible otherwise. She also draws enough comparisons to more recent history (many from the two World Wars) to explain how and why events unfolded.<br /><br />Given the book's length (it took me several weeks to read, despite reading over lunch and a good-sized commute) I can't really recommend it to someone who really wants to know about particular events of the 1300s. Many good books have been written about both the Hundred Years' War and Black Death. But if you're looking for a history of the century as a whole, rather than just the plague or the war, this is a good book.

1565117808|5.0|For me, the best books are those that leave much up to the interpretation of their readers. Authors have difficulty pulling this off, mainly because publishers (at least I believe it's the publishers and/or editors at these houses) enjoy stories that spell out every last detail, leaving nothing to the imaginations of the reading population. Sometimes--rarely--a book comes along that is not only told well, with memorable characters and a compelling story, but it also allows debate once you've finished it. Such is The Life of Pi.<br /><br />Yann Martel (author) gives us this gem that starts out slow and picks up speed until the very end, where the debate as to \\"what really happened to Pi\\" begins.<br /><br />We're introduced to the narrator, Piscine Molitor Patel, in his hometown of Pondicherry, India. Surrounded by animals at this father's zoo, we learn the creatures that inhabit this place are an integral part of Pi. Also integral to Pi's life is his belief in God, but Pi \\"attracts religions like a dog attracts fleas\\" and he finds himself a Christian, a Muslim, and a Hindu on the same day (much to the dismay of his parents). It is his faith in God that will help pull Pi through the most trying event in his life: surviving on a lifeboat for 227 days. But I'm jumping ahead.<br /><br />The book is part and parcel told by a writer who's trying to get Pi's story out of him but having great difficulty. This unknown author visits Pi at his home in Canada where our story begins and ends. Pi's life is one of rarity and hardship overcome by internal strength. And it is this story that underlies the telling of Pi's young life.<br /><br />When Pi's father decides to sell the zoo and transport his family across the sea to Canada (in search of a better life), the boat they are on sinks. Pi is the only survivor. Strike that. Pi is the only human survivor. When he plops into a lifeboat, he quickly discovers that he has an orangutang, a zebra, a hyena, and a Bengal tiger named Richard Parker accompanying him. As animal nature would have it, though, the lifeboats occupants are quickly whittled down to Richard Parker and Pi (it's noteworthy to mention this isn't some anthropomorphic cartoon story where animals talk and are friendly to humans). Having been closely associated with animals in his father's zoo, Pi takes on the challenge of training Richard Parker, teaching the man-eater which side of the boat is his and which is Pi's. An understanding develops and the tiger and boy live together on the boat for months and months, surviving each other as much as famine, thirst, sharks, and storms.<br /><br />Once the boat lands (in Mexico), Richard Parker summarily takes off and is never heard from again. Pi is rescued by beachcombers and sent to a hospital. Here he meets up with two Japanese officials, employees of the company that own the sunken ship. Questions arise and disbelief is confronted. How could a boy survive on a lifeboat with a carnivorous tiger for over seven months? The Japanese men ask for another story, one that \\"doesn't involve animals\\" and it is here that readers have to make up their own minds. Did it happen the way Pi said it did the first time? Or is this ending version the true story? I'm not going to give away what this is; suffice to say it is compelling and intriguing and will probably blow your mind.<br /><br />This novel certainly ranks up there with my favorite reads in the past few years. I'm sure I'll read it again ...and again ...and again, just to see which story of Pi's I truly believe.amed Richard Parker accompanying him. As animal nature would have it, though, the lifeboats occupants are quickly whittled down to Richard Parker and Pi (it's noteworthy to mention this isn't some anthropomorphic cartoon story where animals talk and are friendly to humans). Having been closely associated with animals in his father's zoo, Pi takes on the challenge of training Richard Parker, teaching the man-eater which side of the boat is his and which is Pi's. An understanding develops and the tiger and boy live together on the boat for months and months, surviving each other as much as famine, thirst, sharks, and storms.  <br /> <br />Once the boat lands (in Mexico), Richard Parker summarily takes off and is never heard from again. Pi is rescued by beachcombers and sent to a hospital. Here he meets up with two Japanese officials, employees of the company that own the sunken ship. Questions arise and disbelief is confronted. How could a boy survive on a lifeboat with a carnivorous tiger for over seven months? The Japanese men ask for another story, one that \\"doesn't involve animals\\" and it is here that readers have to make up their own minds. Did it happen the way Pi said it did the first time? Or is this ending version the true story? I'm not going to give away what this is; suffice to say it is compelling and intriguing and will probably blow your mind.  <br /> <br />This novel certainly ranks up there with my favorite reads in the past few years. I'm sure I'll read it again ...and again ...and again, just to see which story of Pi's I truly believe.

B00000JXVK|5.0|When this movie was being shot in 1970, I was an active District 36 MX racer in Northern California.  The word went out that there was this movie that the makers would like to have reviewed by some real racers.  So many of us convened at the old Sacramento Memorial Auditorium for a private showing of the film.  We then were asked to rate it.  (I was surprised, but not that surprised to see a guy who had been a temporary guest at our house in the Steve McQueen MX section, leading Mr. McQueen - (the one with the tire marks on the yellow jersey whose initials are JH))!  So we all gave it our approval and the rest is history.  Later, at the 1971 Saddleback Park InterAm, (or Trans AMA by then) the filmakers took a parade lap in a dune buggy before the race started - in silence.  I was there for that too.  30 plus years later, I saw the film again and thought that it was a little condescending to everything but professional AMA racing, poking a lot of fun at the grassroots - sportsman riders.  But regardless of that, this film represents a historical document when MX was quickly becoming a popular race form in the U.S. It is good to have it as it is, but it would have been even better if more personalities of the day had been included rather than focusing on a handful of favorites.  (I always liked Steve McQueen, but he was not a champion racer ever).  But I don't wish to look back into a gift-horses mouth, we are fortunate to have ANY film from that period - and a sort of arbitrary McQueen document also exists because of this film.  (Note, the end sand sequence was shot at Pismo Beach, CA).

B000FGGE68|3.0|When Kurt Wimmer wrote and directed \\"Equilibrium,\\" he managed to make a wonderful, lower-budget sci-fi flick that had a great story, plenty of action, and solid performances from actors such as the wonderful Christian Bale, Sean Bean, Taye Diggs, and Emily Watson.  When Wimmer cranked out \\"Ultraviolet,\\" he was given a larger budget, an established action star in Milla Jovovich, and a really creepy kid who is perfect at playing a creepy kid (Cameron Bright).  So what does he do with these seemingly win-win elements?  He goes heavy, VERY heavy, on the action, heavy on the CGI, and tosses the actual acting performances to the wayside.<br /><br />Jovovich, Bright, and underrated character actor William Fichtner (also of \\"Equilibrium\\"), have absolutely nothing to work with in this story.  The reed-thin plot is based around Violet (Jovovich), a hemophage who's out to capture a weapon that can supposedly eliminate her kind on Earth.  It seems that every disease in the universe has been wiped out except for one that makes its victims look and act like vampires.  After capturing the weapon, however, Violet begins to question the motives of both her allies and her enemies and all of it sort of smashes along at breakneck speed until there is no one left to kill on the screen.<br /><br />This film wreaks of echoes of \\"Equilibrium.\\"  From the armed soldiers who explode into powdery shards to the clean white uniforms worn by Violet and others in the flick, it seems as if Wimmer took what he felt were the coolest parts of his cult hit and threw it into this film hoping to cash in on it once again.  Even the gun-kata is tossed in!<br /><br />Visually, this is like a video game gone awry.  There's enough eye candy here to send you into fits.  Bright colors everywhere, chameleon-like outfit changes by Violet, and weapons that appear out of the air.  Wimmer unloaded his bag of visual tricks on this one.<br /><br />There is plenty of action here.  If that's your bag, you'll be right at home with \\"Ultraviolet.\\"  However, if you enjoy an actual storyline to go along with the explosions and swordplay, I'd suggest you buy \\"Equilibrium\\" and leave \\"Ultraviolet\\" as a rental only.<br /><br />Not really recommended, unless you really enjoy action and nothing else.e right at home with \\"Ultraviolet.\\"  However, if you enjoy an actual storyline to go along with the explosions and swordplay, I'd suggest you buy \\"Equilibrium\\" and leave \\"Ultraviolet\\" as a rental only. <br /> <br />Not really recommended, unless you really enjoy action and nothing else.

B000059Z8J|5.0|I was born in 1976, so I spent most of my developmental years in the wonderful 80's.  Although I was still a bit young when \\"Superman-The Movie\\" hit the big screen, I caught up with him through VHS and television.  Plenty have donned the red cape, from George Reeves to Dean Cain and everyone in between.  Brandon Routh, who I have yet to see in the latest film, is the current hero of the day.  Christopher Reeve was, is, and always will be Superman to me.  I don't care how hokey the special effects look in this particular flick or how bad the third and fourth films were, Reeve is the Man of Steel in my opinion.<br /><br />This film gives us the origination story of Kal-El, son of Jor-El, of the planet known as Krypton.  If you've been around for a few years, you probably know the rest of the story, so I'll skip that and just stick with the performances of the actors and actresses.  I've gloated on Reeve enough, but I have to admit that his bungling, country-tinged Clark Kent is perfect.  He does a complete 180 degree turn when he rips open his business suit and that \\"S\\" bursts onto the scene.  Lois Lane is done with sassy flair by the great Margot Kidder.  She, much like Reeve, has become her character in my mind.  Gene Hackman hams it up as Superman's arch enemy, Lex Luthor.  His over-the-top performance is fun to watch on the screen.  Ned Beatty portrays the bumbling sidekick, Otis, and Valerie Perrine is a scene stealer as the luscious Eve.  Marlon Brando is sufficient as Kent's father, but his performance comes across as rather wooden.  Terence Stamp (General Zod), Jack O'Halloran (Non), and Maria Schell (Vond-Ah) have sinister small roles in this feature, but set the stage well for \\"Superman II.\\"  The rest of the cast, primarily reduced to supporting roles, do a wonderful job with what they have to work with.<br /><br />As stated before, the special effects are pretty hokey by today's standards, but they were top-notch in 1978.  They help move the story along at a decent pace without hindering the performers on the screen.<br /><br />This film set a high standard for future comic book-based films.  While many have met, and in some cases surpassed, this standard, \\"Superman\\" will always be considered the first of the great modern comic flicks.<br /><br />Highly recommended to any fan of comic flicks, or anyone who just wants to relive the excitement of seeing ol' Superman fly for the first time!at a decent pace without hindering the performers on the screen. <br /> <br />This film set a high standard for future comic book-based films.  While many have met, and in some cases surpassed, this standard, \\"Superman\\" will always be considered the first of the great modern comic flicks. <br /> <br />Highly recommended to any fan of comic flicks, or anyone who just wants to relive the excitement of seeing ol' Superman fly for the first time!
B00005JOQS|5.0|Like the citizens of Metropolis, I didn't realize how much I missed the Man of Steel until I once again witnessed Clark Kent (Brandon Routh) running down Main Street, shedding his clothes and setting sail to save the day for the first time in Bryan Singer's big, beautiful, fast paced, masculine yet very touching take on the Superman franchise, \\"Superman Returns.\\"<br />Routh's Kent/Superman, a superb creation of director Bryan Singer (\\"Usual Suspects,\\" \\"XMen\\"), Dan Harris (\\"Imaginary Heroes) and others, is as usual naÃ¯ve, befuddled and endearing as Kent but this Superman, along with being strong, upstanding, driven and sure of himself, is also very emotional and human...a mensch: outwardly a product of the love bestowed upon him by his adoring adopted mother (Eva Marie Saint) and his girlfriend Lois Lane (Kate Bosworth).<br />Much of \\"SR\\" is jaw-droppingly gorgeous thanks to the superior work of Production Designer Guy Dyas and the visuals of Newton Thomas Sigel (\\"Three Kings,\\" \\"Brothers Grimm\\"). In fact the first rescue sequence involving an aborted launch of a space shuttle with Lois on hand is truly amazing both in physical execution and emotional impact. Also of note is the way in which Superman levitates throughout the film: on the one hand almost balletic in movement on the other very much akin to the mechanical movement of a heliocopter.<br />\\"Superman Returns\\" and I for one am glad he's back.
B0009R1T7M|5.0|I don't think I have ever taken the trouble to review anything before, but I feel compelled to promote the talents of Sufjan Stevens. The Copland-like rhythms, the feeling of open spaces, the broad range of subjects and ideas and the memorable melodies urge me to listen to this CD over and over again.  I never tire of it.  I believe his \\"Michigan\\" album reveals itself as a predecessor of \\"Come Hear the Illinois!\\" in the melodic schemes, but they mature into an incomparable album here.  Also look for Sufjan's \\"Seven Swans\\" which has strong and haunting mystical, Christian and just lovely imagery in it, as well as tunes to return to repeatedly.  My two favorites.  I look forward to the next album!

But this album lacks the flow of Transatlanticism or the solid sound of The Photo Album.  The tracks(even the weaker ones) are good for the most part (I am not a fan of \\"Summer Skin\\") but there are the obvious \\"better\\" tracks and the others seem to cower in the wake of the \\"I Will Follow You into the Dark\\"s and the \\"Soul Meets Body\\"s and are there to fill the gaps between them. <br /> <br />This is a good album, however. Very few moments are anywhere near bad and most are very good.  But the imagination of some of the earlier works seems to be lacking somewhat and the album as a whole will grow staler quicker than Death Cab's earlier efforts.      <br /> <br />I truly believe that if this were from any other group it would be worthy of a 5 star rating; DCfC's past works are just so strong that a 3 1/2 - 4 star rating is deserved and even generous.  I am not kidding or lying when I say this is a good album; it is. But it is just not outstanding. Death Cab seems to be just biding some time until their next effort comes along to hopefully pull us back in.

B00005NQLP|4.0|The 1977 \\"CSN\\" album had been a smash hit for Crosby, Stills & Nash.  In typical fashion, the guys just couldn't get their heads together for a follow-up, not least due to Crosby's descent into \\"drug madness\\" (as Nash puts it), which also did away with a reuniting of the Crosby * Nash duo team.  So, Nash decided to carry on with a solo record, his third, with \\"Earth & Sky\\" coming out in early 1980.    Basically, this album sounds exactly like you would expect.  It's a soft rock album all the way, totally sounding like it was recorded in 1979 or '80--a booming drum sound, chorused rhythm guitars, tinkling electric pianos, etc.  If you're a sucker for that kind of sound (and I don't fault you if you are!), you'll really like this album.      No, it's not a masterpiece.  \\"Skychild\\" and \\"Helicopter Song\\" are forgettable, and the ballad \\"Magical Child\\" is okay but suffers from sickly sweetness.      It's often great though.  The title track has that trademark lilting Graham Nash melodicism (it features instantly recognizable slide guitar from Joe Walsh).  \\"Love Has Come\\" is a wonderful soft-rock ballad.  The waltzing \\"It's All Right\\" is another soft-rock ballad, similar in theme to \\"Love Has Come\\", and it's a little cheesy and brought down by toothless female vocals toward the end, but it's still very pleasant.  The starkly-arranged, yet dreamy, minor-keyed \\"Out On The Island\\" is simply blissful; and heard today, it curiously seems to foreshadow the title track for David Gilmour's \\"On An Island\\", the latter of which Nash even sings background vocals on!  The anthemic \\"Barrel Of Pain (Half-Life)\\", another in a large stack of late '70s songs written about the dangers of nuclear waste, is quite powerful.  And the rousing, quick-paced album-closer \\"In The 80's\\" is infectiously upbeat, optimistic, and catchy.    All in all, this is not quite as well-written as 1971's \\"Songs For Beginners\\", nor is it as insanely catchy as 1986's \\"Innocent Eyes\\", but \\"Earth & Sky\\" is still highly worthwhile.      However, I recommend you steer clear of the Magic Records CD release of \\"Earth & Sky\\"; providing you have a quality turntable, you'd almost undoubtedly be better off with the original vinyl.  I've gotten a couple of other CD reissues from Magic, and they each have incredibly cruddy remastering, clearly done from either vinyl or cassette copies--may the buyer beware.
034544678X|3.0|Patricia McConnell's book is a good read for dog lovers/owners, but it's an amalgamation of training tips, anthropologic observations, science of evolution, and personal anecdotes.  If you are looking for a training guide to use in working with your dog, read this because it's interesting, but you'll still need a training manual.
B000002I6X|4.0|Much has been made about 1971's \\"Stephen Stills 2\\" being a major disappointment that suffers from egregious overproduction.  Yes, this is a clear dropoff in quality from Stills' first solo album from 1970, but not a HUGE dropoff.  Even with its flaws, this is still a solid effort.    \\"Nothin' To Do But Today\\" is a super fun, laidback country-blues rocker.  The droning folk tune \\"Know You Got To Run\\" is captivating and hypnotic, with revealing lyrics reportedly written about Neil Young (and partially recycled from \\"Everybody I Love You\\").  \\"Singin' Call\\" is a soothing acoustic ballad.  \\"Marianne\\" is an irresistible, swinging pop-rocker graced by Stephen's excellent falsetto vocals.  \\"Fishes And Scorpions\\" starts off ultra-dreamy, with its intertwining layers of reverb-laden guitar and Stephen's smooth vocals, and it works up to a fiery guitar solo.  \\"Relaxing Town\\" rocks, although it has a sadly anti-climactic sudden ending.  \\"Sugar Babe\\", extremely similar to the previous album's \\"Church (Part of Someone)\\", is well-written and effective in its own right, although marred by the excessive fuzz bass/ guitar.      In all likelihood, the most well-known/ well-remembered song from the album is the album-opener \\"Change Partners\\"--it's a nicely-melodic country pop-rocker, but it's a little overcooked, with disjointed shifts from the 3/4 verses to the 4/4 chorus.  \\"Marianne\\", like \\"Change Partners\\", also reached the top 50 of the US Billboard Singles chart.  But probably the second most well-known song here is the Dylan-esque \\"Word Game\\", which is a mixed bag--blatantly structured like \\"It's Alright Ma (I'm Only Bleeding)\\", Stephen resorts to misguided sloppy rambling, despite his excellent, moody acoustic guitar backing.    Speaking of misguided...  For whatever reason, Stills seems to have taken fancy to Chicago--the band that is--as evident by the three horn-soaked numbers \\"Open Secret\\", \\"Ecology Song\\", and \\"Bluebird Revisited\\", and considering Chicago's incredible lameness up to that time (in large part anyway, the classic \\"Beginnings\\" notwithstanding), this is a damn shame indeed.  The horn arrangement on \\"Ecology Song\\" is laughably schlocky and obnoxious, sounding EXACTLY like late '60s/ early '70s Chicago, plus it's got an awful song-ending trumpet/ flugelhorn solo.  The extended, conga-heavy instrumental coda on \\"Open Secret\\" is again unmistakeably reminiscent of contemporaneous Chicago; however, the main song portion of it is excellently-written and even moving, and thankfully doesn't suffer TOO badly from horn excess.    Stephen Stills was a real ambitious dude back in the early '70s, and although his ambitions didn't serve him as well on \\"Stephen Stills 2\\" as they had on its predecessor, this is still a strong collection with Stills' enormous talent very much in evidence.
B0007OY2P8|1.0|This is one of the worst shows we've ever seen and that's saying a lot.  It's on a par with Peter Ustinov playing Charlie Chan, 30, or more, years ago.  That movie was funny where it shouldn't have been and sad where it was supposed to be funny.  Gosh, it was bad--did anyone see us leaving the theater?  This version of Northanger Abbey is every bit as bad or worse. <br /> <br />Lately, my wife and I have been going over Jane Austen DVD's and videotapes we've acquired or made.  Included were DVD's we'd rate as follows: \\"Persuasion,\\" 4 stars; \\"Pride and Prejudice,\\" the 1979, BBC production, 5 stars; the 1995 A&E production of \\"Pride and Prejudice,\\" 5+ stars; and \\"Sense and Sensibility,\\" 5 stars.  Then, we saw \\"Emma,\\" another A&E production we videotaped from the mid-90's and found it charming and entertaining.  \\"Emma\\" might be considered lighter fare than P&P and S&S, but it's still very good, 4+ stars. <br /> <br />So we kept looking for more Jane Austen and found \\"Northanger Abbey,\\" something we'd taped off A&E and never had time to watch.  In short, this 1986 production bears no comparison with the others mentioned and would warrant less than 1 star, if we could give it. <br /> <br />When we saw that Robert Hardy was featured in this production of \\"Northanger Abbey,\\" we felt encouraged that it should be good.  We admired his work in the long-running BBC series, \\"All Creatures Great and Small.\\"  More so, he was great in his portrayal of Winston Churchill in another BBC series, \\"The Wilderness Years.\\"  But in Northanger he is poor, at best.  His character struts around in a red coat most of the time, making snide remarks.  He and the other characters are all without redeeming features and we couldn't care less what happened to them in the end.  They were either foppish or self-important, or just ridiculous. <br /> <br />As to the female lead, Catherine Schlesinger, we had to throw up our hands, lest our dinner.  Just a short time into the show we could see how miscast she was for the part and how poorly the director had handled her.  She's all bug-eyes-and-mouth open, at the drop of a hat.  One had to wonder if there were cue cards being flashed behind the camera: Bug Eyes; Open Mouth.  It was very irritating. <br /> <br />Background music was weird and very poor.  It sounded like saxophones and synthesizer--a recipe for disaster.  If the music were playing while the director and screenwriter were doing their work it might explain why the story was so disjointed and chaotic. <br /> <br />Lessons learned from the time wasted on this dreadful piece include the fact that the BBC doesn't automatically mean high quality.  Similarly, a Jane Austen adaptation doesn't always mean a good, coherent story.  Then, if you're planning to pay good money for a DVD, check the reviews posted on Amazon.com, before buying. If we'd paid for the DVD, we'd be really peeved.  Giles Foster was the director of Northanger and we'll be watching out for him in future.  Same for the screenwriter, Maggie Wadey. <br /> <br />We've read what others have to say about \\"Northanger Abbey\\" and have no interest in reading the book or seeing a re-make.  In essence, we've heard that Jane Austen intended this piece to be a satire on gothic novels of her time.  But there's no satire here.  The screenwriter and director seem to have taken the story line straight and totally lost the point.  Although we'd agree that Jane Austen could never have intended for the story to be so messed up, we don't want to be reminded of what it was like to endure this tripe. Nevertheless, we did get a few laughs reading the Amazon reviews after viewing the show.  Many were brutal and deservedly so.

0451191153|5.0|I started reading this book at the suggestion of a friend, and I couldn't put it down. The first 100 pages or so are kind of slow by modern standards, but after those 100 pages I was completely and definitively hooked. I think that what most attracted me to the book was the author's belief in the beauty and triumph of the true human spirit. I was born in a communist country and later raised in a climate of uncertainty that directly resulted from the mind-numbing policies of the \\"red plague\\" as I call it; I think this must be at least part of the reason why Ayn Rand's book resonated so deeply within me. Her viewpoint is quite extreme, so don't expect to agree with everything-you won't! Her message, though, stands beyond any disagreements I or anybody else might have. This book truly inspired me to give it my best, to be true to myself, and to never stop believing in my abilities . Also, I have come to appreciate the beauty of selfishness as Ayn Rand defines it. Selfishness, in her world, is living your life for yourself and eliminating the need to live in order to receive others' approval. In short, this is a great introduction to Ayn Rand's body of work as it lays the foundation for the later books including Atlas Shrugged.

B00000JR29|5.0|Tears For Fears followed their hit debut THE HURTING with this album, 1985's SONGS FROM THE BIG CHAIR.  At first glance, it appears to be just another pop album from the 1980s, but after one listen, it's clear that SONGS FROM THE BIG CHAIR is anything but.  It's a collection of brilliant songs spawned from the angst and inner turmoil of bass guitarist/vocalist Curt Smith, guitarist/keyboardist/vocalist Roland Orzabal, keyboardist Ian Stanley, and drummer Manny Elias.  Together, the songs form a masterpiece that is not only one of the best albums of the decade - it's one of the greatest albums ever made.  It spawned two Number 1 hits: the powerful, razor-sharp \\"Shout\\", and \\"Everbody Wants To Rule The World\\", a song which perfectly encapsulates the mood of the 1980s.  There's plenty more greats here, though, such as the atmospheric \\"Mothers Talk\\" and the glimmering \\"Head Over Heels\\" (recently featured in Richard Kelly's cult hit film DONNIE DARKO).  The apocalyptic \\"The Working Hour\\" is another gem, which features a great saxophone part played by Mel Collins and William Gregory.  SONGS FROM THE BIG CHAIR is an album which truly is like no other.  Don't let its commercial success fool you; from \\"Shout\\" to the ethereal \\"Listen\\" - complete with heavenly vocals - this is art, fueled by powerful lyrics and a turbulent, emotional sound.    TRACK HIGHLIGHTS: Shout, The Working Hour, Everybody Wants To Rule The World, Mothers Talk, Head Over Heels/Broken [Live], Listen
B00005JOQS|4.0|This latest Superman film is entertaining. In it, Superman returns to Earth after a five-year absence (he was searching space for Krypton) to find the planet plagued by crime, Lex Luthor released from jail, and Lois Lane married with a child. Superman struggles with readjusting to things while Luthor crafts a plot to create himself new real estate (despite the damage it will do to the real estate already existing). <br /> <br />A decent film. Kevin Spacey is wonderful as Lex Luthor, as expected. Bosworth, however, disappoints a little as Lois Lane--she was, perhaps, too soft; Lois needs to be tougher and have a little bit more of an edge. Parker Posey has a wonderful little role as Luthor's moll--she stands out (in a good way). While the action scenes are exciting, there is a lot of time in-between them. While I didn't have much of a problem with it, most everyone in my party said that the film was \\"too slow\\" after we watched. Perhaps the best surprise of the film was the opening credit sequence: it is a throwback to the original 80s credits, including reusing John Williams' magnificent score. Good choice; it would've been mighty hard to top it--one of the best scores in movie history. <br /> <br />The worst thing I have to say about Superman Returns is that it is, perhaps, not the movie it could've been. Other recent superhero films have established that there's great potential left in them. While Superman Returns is good, and fun, it does not fully engage that potential save for small moments and characters, most notably Spacey's Luthor. Still, whatever the critics say, this is an entertaining film you're likely to enjoy.  <br /> <br />Four stars.
B00064WSNW|5.0|If you listen with your ears and mind open, that is.  I swear, anyone who has ANYTHING even slightly uncomplementary to say about this album has wax in their ears, is mentally off, or a combination of the two.  Everything about this album is perfect from the amazing guitar interplay of Fripp, Belew, and Levin to the provocative, deft, and meaningful lyrics of Belew.  The album starts off with a lazy, dissonant vamp that quickly evolves into hyperkinetic proportions and there is no getting off of this ride after that point.  \\"Talk, it's only talk,\\" Belew starts, going into an alphabetical catalog of different kinds of talk: \\"dialogue, duologue, dissension, declamation, double-talk, double-talk,\\" he intones as he and the band weave a hypnotic electric/electronic soundscape.  Everything is firing so well here that drummer nonpareil Bill Bruford manages to make electronic drums stunning, of all things.  The only other drummer I can think of to do this is jazz giant Jack DeJohnette.<br /><br />Man, I could write my dissertation on this album.  But if I do that, I'll never write my real dissertation.  So the skinny on the rest.  \\"Frame by Frame\\": \\"in your eyes, in your eyes, analysis,\\" Belew's central lyric here, pretty well sums it up.  In other words, you can't completely sum this song up, as well any of the others here; they do what Flannery O'Connor said good fiction should: it defies paraphrase.  You sit there and marvel at the infinite web Fripp and Co. have created, more limitless than any that Fripp & Co. wove on any album before or since, as another reviewer here (along with Fripp) suggests.<br /><br />\\"Frame by Frame\\" continues the angular contours set out in \\"Elephant Talk,\\" but these let out on the unabashedly lyrical \\"Matte Kudasai.\\"  On display here are Belew's loving lyrics that surge and swell like the real thing, somehow managing never to be sentimental or hackneyed (\\"a miracle\\"!), a trait that he, unlike any other Crimso vocalist, in my opinion, had never fully possessed before him.  This stunning vocal and lyrical performance is backed by an appropriately surging and swooping instrumental performance.<br /><br />Next is the song that hooked me for life when I was fourteen and has never ceased to entertain vigorously in the hundreds of times I have listened to it in the two decades since.  \\"Indiscipline\\" is, in short, a postmodern paranoid masterpiece, certainly no less than \\"21st Century Schizoid Man.\\"  Belew shares a monologue about an object he is obsessed with (\\"the more I look at it, the more I like it,/ I do think it's good [. . .] no matter how I take it apart/ It remains consistent\\"); alas, we never find out exactly what it is (\\"I wish you were here to see it,\\" Belew snorts).  We are led to surmise that this object is his consciousness, making this song perhaps the most successful musical conception of the Beckettian Unnamable (or Cartesian cogito) that there has ever been.<br /><br />Aaaahhhhh . . . and then \\"Thela Hun Ginjeet.\\"  A swelling sung intro that leads into a tape recording of an interview with a young man who went into a \\"dangerous place.\\"  The instruments snarl and are strummed frenetically like in the previous song, creating a sort of pre-industrial thrum; again, completely appropriate to the paranoid inner-city setting of the piece.  The moods fluctuate unpredictably and deftly here, from a tribal sort of collective expression in the sung portions to an insular feel in the found-sound sections.<br /><br />\\"The Sheltering Sky\\" is a meditative instrumental piece that highlights Frippertronics and the emerging world music influence on what I am going to call post-prog (think about it, this isn't the prog of \\"Court of the Crimson King\\" or ELP's \\"Karn Evil 9\\"; this is prog with new wave and punk influences [more of the rough stuff!!!] , world music: in other words it has moved past prog's original parameters--largely classical- and jazz-inspired--and along with and into history . . .).  Bruford'srestrained percussion here is also noteworthy.<br /><br />The CD ends with \\"Discipline,\\" another instrumental piece, bringing the whole transcendent ordeal full circle with mind-reeling mathematical patterns that tame the shrieking excesses of the songs constellated around \\"Indiscipline.\\"  No band does math rock as effectively, provocatively, and intellectually as this.  Hell, they move you emotionally as they do it, something few other technically-oriented bands can do.  It's due to Belew's lyrical genius, in contradistinction to less successful Crimso leaders of yore, and how that translates into each and every band member's playing.<br /><br />In short, buy this now.  If you've yet to hear this, you have a lifetime of shivers up and down your spine to catch up on.  A masterpiece that no one can claim to have topped . . .Bruford's restrained percussion here is also noteworthy. <br /> <br />The CD ends with \\"Discipline,\\" another instrumental piece, bringing the whole transcendent ordeal full circle with mind-reeling mathematical patterns that tame the shrieking excesses of the songs constellated around \\"Indiscipline.\\"  No band does math rock as effectively, provocatively, and intellectually as this.  Hell, they move you emotionally as they do it, something few other technically-oriented bands can do.  It's due to Belew's lyrical genius, in contradistinction to less successful Crimso leaders of yore, and how that translates into each and every band member's playing. <br /> <br />In short, buy this now.  If you've yet to hear this, you have a lifetime of shivers up and down your spine to catch up on.  A masterpiece that no one can claim to have topped . . .  <br />
B000BNX3AU|3.0|There are a couple of reasons why the movie \\"Must Love Dogs\\" appealed to me.   The first reason is that I like movies that don't have the big \\"megastar\\" in it.     I like to give a movie a chance on its merit as opposed to its star power.     The second reason is - yes, I like Romantic Comedies.   This may seem odd coming from a thirtysomething male, but yes I happen to be a fan of the romantic comedy.    Therefore with two ingredients getting a thumbs-up in my book, I figured the movie \\"Must Love Dogs\\" was one worth checking.   Overall, I thought the movie was good - but unfortunately the movie does fall short in some areas and therefore cannot be considered one of the great romantic comedies of recent years. <br /> <br />The focus of the movie revolves around a preschool teacher Sarah Nolan (played by Diane Lane).  Sarah has recently been divorced and is looking to get back into the dating game and find \\"Mr. Right\\".   At the same time, her sisters are also looking to help Sarah find the right guy.    Sarah's sister Carol (played by Elizabeth Perkins) puts her profile on an internet dating service.   After a series of failures, Sarah manages to meet up with a romantic boat builder named Jake Anderson (played by John Cusack).   Jake is in a similar situation to Sarah in that he is recently divorced and has his best friend Charlie prodding at him to get back in the dating game.   At the same time, Sarah meets Bob Connor (played by Delmot Mulroney) - the father of one of her students.   The dynamics between Sarah and these two men are really what will ignite the storyline.   Sarah definitely sees some \\"potential\\" with Jake, but also sees a connection with Bob.    Eventually things will come to a head between Sarah, Jake, and Bob - and as a result Sarah's life will be more complicated than ever. <br /> <br />The strong point of this movie is the performance of Sarah by Diane Lane.   Lane is one of those actresses who has done a steady body of work for about 20 years, yet still seems to have superstardom allude her.   The character of Sarah was one that was both \\"peppy\\" and reserved.    Lane seemed to nail this character down and fit the character's role like a glove.   It is Lane that is going to provide some of the film's most humorous moments - particularly the parts when she is engaging in the internet dating service.    I've read a lot of reviews that said that it is going to be her character that is quickly going to be the film's main force.   I couldn't agree more with those reviews.   I'm not sure that even the \\"big name\\" romantic comedy actresses (like Meg Ryan, Julia Roberts, Renee Zellweger, and Sandra Bullock) could have pulled off this role as well as Lane. <br /> <br />On the other hand, the leading actor of this film John Cusack does nothing for me.    I think blame could be shared between Cusack and the film's writers and producers.   Despite the fact that Cusack also has had a steady body of work, I can't say I have been very impressed with John Cusack's body of work.   On top of that, the role of Jake Anderson isn't very exciting or interesting.    While Cusack gets stuck with a lackluster character like Jake, Cusack does little to elevate the character of Jake. <br /> <br />There are two other characters of note in this movie - one positive and one negative.   On the positive end, Christopher Plummer delivers a nice performance as Sarah's father Bill.    Bill is a widower who is also exploring the dating game.  He provides a gentle, but strong presence in the film.    Plummer reminds me a lot of a modern day Cesar Romero in his style to acting - and his performance in this film clearly solidifies this.   On the negative end, Stockard Channing plays Dolly - one of Bill's girlfriends.   Channing plays a 61 year old woman in this movie (which happened to be her age in the movie).    Unfortunately, I found the character of Dolly to be annoying.   While I'm not the biggest Channing fan, she is given a character thatreally isn't the \\"scene stealer\\" that this character had the potential to be.   Thus I must say the character of Dolly is negative. <br /> <br />The opening credits feature some \\"interviews\\" that help set the stage for the theme of the movie (looking for love).   It is worth noting that one of the people interviewed is a character - Vinnie from Brooklyn.  This character is played by Steven R. Schirippa (a.k.a Bobby \\"Bacala\\" from \\"The Sopranos\\").   Schirippa is perfect for this role.    There is also a series of \\"interviews\\" in the closing credits that feature some of the cast members.   The style for all of these interviews was seen in \\"When Harry Met Sally\\".   They work as well in \\"Must Love Dogs\\" as they did in that movie. <br /> <br />Romantic comedies are tough movies to pull off because usually there is a lot of predictability - especially in the endings.    The components of a good romantic comedy will interweave storylines and often have a subplot or two going on.  How good those interweaved storylines or subplots are will usually determine how good the romantic comedy is.  \\"Must Have Dogs\\" is predictable and has a predictable ending. While \\"Must Have Dogs\\" has Lane's presence and some funny moments, it lacks these components to help overcome the predictability. <br /> <br />Overall, this movie can best be summed up as a good romantic comedy.   There have been better ones - there have been worse ones.  Still I think this one is worth checking out - if not for Diane Lane's performance alone.  While I gave this movie a chance on merit as opposed to star power, it did fall a bit short.   Therefore I'd moderately recommend this one.

This was perhaps my favorite movie of 2005.

I do not mean to bash it and I hope it doesn't sound that way. 0671015206|4.0|The Millionaire Next Door is a good first book for the budding investor. There are many approaches to gaining wealth, and this book takes the slow, steady, and safest route to financial independence. Frugality is a recurring theme in the book, and simple arithmetic does show the authors' research to be accurate. Even the next generation of high-rolling stock brokers needs seed money, and the Millionaire Next Door really hammers home the need to save. <br /> <br />Another interesting facet of the book is insight into the millionaire mindset. Most people think of millionaires as caviar-eating, Rolls-Royce driving top hats. That may be the case in some situations, but the average millionaire is an entrepreneur that lives below his means. One thing I wanted to learn more about was actual investing. I look at this book as the first step on the road to solvency. Also helpful is the advice on how to handle your kids after you make the big bucks. Think you're helping them with endless cash gifts? Read this book. <br /> <br />As a young, novice investor, personal finance seems to be a mix of knowledge, luck, and logic. I'm sure there is more, but I would definitely recommend the Millionaire Next Door to anyone who has a little money and wants a little more. Financial independence is not so much of a recipe as it is a garden; you need to tend it regularly and wisely for success. And the fruits are not guaranteed even when you do everything right.  However, books like these provide a good starting ground into a complicated topic.   <br />

B00007LTIC|5.0|This is a spectacular album, the unnecessary bonus tracks notwithstanding, and almost singlehandedly rescued the reputation of this band, which had been tarnished by the horrifying \\"Tales From Topographic Oceans\\" and the tepid \\"Relayer\\".    Every track here is like its own universe, and there are stunning moments from each player as well as tremendous collective songcraft and beautiful, uncluttered production.  Hell, I even like Alan White's playing on this one, and I usually can't stand him.  I kind of feel sorry for him actually, because following Bill Bruford in a band has gotta be a bit like following Jesus at the Jerusalem Hilton.  Just ask Pat Mastelotto.    This record is quite a ride, beginning with the crunchy steel guitar madness of the title track (punctuated by the singer's humorously self-effacing words deriding his overly \\"cosmic mind\\").  This song almost sounds like a cross between \\"Heart of the Sunrise\\" from Fragile and the Flying Burrito Brothers' \\"Train Song,\\" if you can imagine such a thing without having your head spontaneously explode.    The next tune is a Yes classic of storytelling, about a sculptor whose muse dies, leaving him to attempt to resurrect her out of stone in his work.  The peaks of this song are just over the moon, culminating with the transcendent guitar part that comes out of the line about how \\"when we're young, love lingers so\\" and punctuated throughout by ultra-gorgeous acoustic arabesques from the fingers of Howe and an floaty, enveloping soundstage production-wise.  My personal favorite on this disc and maybe my all-time favorite Yessong.    Next is the Squire showcase, the fat-bottomed \\"Parallels,\\" which sounds not unlike \\"Hold Out Your Hand\\" from his then-current solo record, the excellent Fish Out of Water.  Great super-churchy organ from the Caped Crusader here, as well as some nice multitracking on the voices.  This features that trademark, diatonic, positive mood this band was/is famous for.    On side two we begin with a brief, lush sing-along and proceed into the conclusion of the original LP with one of the great Yes epics, \\"Awaken,\\" which just soars along like the Earth at 60,000 MPH at that moment in the morning when the sun breaks your particular horizon.  To call \\"Awaken\\" celestial in character would be like calling Black Sabbath \\"loud\\".    Anyhow like I said the bonus cuts are needless, but the original album is so good that it doesn't matter.  The booklet, however, was very well done with all kinds of new photos (including the one from the original LP gatefold where the naughty, half-hidden smoking apparatus is visible!).
B000000HU1|5.0|The third installment of the Trilogy is my personal favorite, probably because there's less singing and more blistering playing, especially from Steve Hillage and the immortal \\"Bloomdido\\" Malherbe.  Of course all three installments are required \\"PHP 101\\" course material but if you were just dipping your toe into the waters of this most singular & amazing band I might suggest \\"You\\" as the place to begin, if only because it seems a bit more streamlined and accessible.  Which is not to say that it isn't completely balls-out nuts either.    The lyrics here are of a more general nature and speak less to the convoluted sci-fi storyline that dominates the preceding two records... of course the Pot Head Pixies and the Octave Doctors are still front-and-center but the words are given over more towards an explication of their general philosophy as characters than to explaining who they are and how they fit in to the Gong Mythology.  Really this album is more of an even split between singing and playing and like I said this gives the instrumentalists space to shine superbly... the sticker on the CD said that You sounds like \\"King Crimson on 10 hits of acid\\" and I for one wouldn't deny the accuracy of such a statement.    As for the copy protection issue, I live in the States and got the US issue, which doesn't have that added feature of shameless evil, so I guess I should rejoice and count my blessings.  All I can say is that if the record companies would focus 1/1000th of the energy they give to preventing \\"theft\\" towards actually providing product that was worth stealing in the first place, we'd live in a better and more expressive world.  But don't hold your breath.    Do, however, buy this and every Gong album from the 1970s because they are essential!
B00007KWHP|5.0|A stunning achievement from the Golden Age of Progressive Rock, when you could put Brahms on your record and not seem/sound like a total prat.    This one and its successor (\\"Close to the Edge\\") kind of belong together, like two sides of the same coin.  Strangely, I think the songs on Fragile are better but Close to the Edge works better as an album.    This contains several Prog standards, including the obvious hit (\\"Roundabout\\"), Long Distance Runaround and the absolutely blistering Heart of the Sunrise, which contains perhaps the funkiest moment in all of Prog (after the first stomping riff section, where everything drops out and it's just the bass and Bill Bruford's ridiculously tasty, triplet-obsessed drums).  But my favorite cut here has gotta be South Side of the Sky, about two guys out hiking in the mountains that freeze to death, of all things to write a song about!  Of course, the sunny, diatonic mood of Yes makes such a harrowing story sound almost happy and welcoming.    Of the solo pieces that dot the record I prefer Steve Howe's flamenco-ish Mood for a Day and the epic Chris Squire sponge-bath called The Fish.  Squire just kind of blows up this whole album, taking the bass to a whole other level in the rock context with his manic Rick-picking style.  Was he the first of the plectrum-using bassists or did Jack Bruce do that first?  I guess the biggest innovation was to tune the bass up higher to match the toppy, one-of-a-kind sound of Bruford's snare... together they form quite a distinctive rhythm section.    Overall this is a helluva record and one of the ten essential Progressive Rock albums of all time.  Plus the remaster sounds fantastic, unlike the muddily crap-tastic original issue... especially as applies to the keyboards provided by the Caped Crusader, which just thoroughly sucked on the old CD of this one.

B000003S0P|5.0|A definitive statement not just of the end of the Golden Age of Progressive Rock, but of the 1960s-style countercultural maelstrom of experimentation that spawned the genre whilst simultaneously changing so much about the greater world forever. <br /> <br />This plays like a wake for \\"the sixties\\" in many ways, most clearly and poignantly on the stunning climactic masterpiece \\"Starless,\\" which is just uber-cinematic in scope and execution.  The horns of the departed Crimson Kings Mel Collins and Ian MacDonald make this almost like the ribbon bow tied on this genre-defining band, like Crimsons past and present colliding in perfect alignment to make a grand, perfect statement of summation about everything this group stood for in its time. <br /> <br />Perhaps more than any other group outside of the Beatles, this band symbolized the ethos of anything-goes experimentation and boundary-shattering creativity that characterized the end of the Piscean Age and the dawning of the Age of Aquarius, i.e., the late 1960s and early 1970s, when old and obsolete modalities of life and living were falling onto the dustbin of history faster than in any other previous cultural revolution in human history. <br /> <br />This group made such an impact with so little observable compromise largely because, beginning when it came on the scene as \\"the next Beatles\\" in early 1969, it continually proved that what everyone thought was possible in Rock Music was only the tip of the proverbial iceberg, and that indeed the only limitation on the breadth of what could be aspired to by the musicians was the inestimable power of their own imaginations.  With each incarnation KC has altered the musical DNA in a certain way, and this album is no exception. <br /> <br />There is nothing to be said about this music that hasn't already been said by the articulate and passionate people who wrote about it previously.  Yes, the compositions are tritonally heavy (that's why it's called \\"Red,\\" as the smoking VU meter on the back cover with its needle pushed all the way to the right attests).  Yes, the vocals of John Wetton never sounded better or had more conviction.  Yes, the drumming is perhaps the greatest ever achieved on a Rock album and proof positive of why Bill Bruford is one of the greatest ever on his instrument in any genre.  But beyond the specifics this is a valedictory for an unprecedented and important period, all too brief and fleeting, in which Music in particular and Humanity in general seemed to be trying to cast off the chains in so many ways. <br /> <br />Bottom line: if you have never discovered this group, you have lucked out because they might be, in terms of creativity and challenge to existing musical structures within the pantheon of Rock, the greatest of all time.  You should buy all of their albums and dive right in, but this masterpiece is surely a fine place to begin.
B0002RGNRU|4.0|I watched this movie recently per a friend's recommendation, when it actually came out I did not have any interest as I am not a big Jim Carrey fan. When I was told Carrey's performance was as good as in `Truman Show' I decided to watch it.<br /><br />The movie basically tells the story of  Joel and Clementine, they had a relationship that did not end well, luckily for both, there is a doctor (Tom Wilkinson) who offers an alternative to suffering from heart breaking: erase all the memories related to a person. While the premise sounds a little too weird (written by Charlie Kauffman who previously gave us `Being John Malkovich'), it establishes a very interesting possibility, what if you could do this? (There is a funny moment in which we get to see an old lady waiting for the memories of her dead puppy to be erased.. if you have suffered the loss of a dog you'll understand). The director makes you think about it for a while; yes, we do all have memories we would wish to go away, but would we do it? Is it better to forget than to face and learn from the experience? The `memory deleting' situation is definitely one of the best moments of the film.<br /><br />And it is because in Joel's `memory deleting' process (which takes the most part of the film), we get to see all their memories together... tender moments that make you realize what a wonderful relationship they had. It is in this moment in which Joel faces the fact that he may not want to delete Clementine from his head. There are other subplots related to the characters who perform the `memory deleting' which are ok but do not add anything of value to the central story of Joel and Clementine.<br /><br />While it has some funny moments the movie is not a comedy, actually Carrey's acting is superb in his character of quiet and indecisive Joel, Kate Winslet performs great as supporting Clementine in Joel's brain while his memories are being deleted.<br /><br />Do not be fooled by the premise of the film, it is a very serious movie about relationships and what we learn from them. Directed by Michel Gondry (who has in his resume some of Bjork's best music videos) you can expect not only a good film but also a very interesting visual experience.t is a very serious movie about relationships and what we learn from them. B0001NBMBC|2.0|Let's flash back to 1999 for a moment...Slipknot, this fresh new band, comes onto the scene with a sound both heavy and angry, something that wasn't being played on the mainstream at all. They follow up the self titled affair with Iowa, a CD that retains the heaviness and anger, ultimately feeling like a perfect companion disc. Now we have Vol. 3: The Subliminal Verses, a CD that was hyped beyond belief by not only the band but also the media.<br /><br />To say that this CD was a disappointment is an understatement. I loved Slipknot because of their unforgiving brand of metal. Cory had one of my favorite voices in music, the band sounded crisp and heavy, etc. But with Vol. 3 Cory dulls his voice to little more than a hearty yell, at no point does he pull out the voice we came to love on the past two releases. As for the band, that intensity just isn't there like it used to be. The CD as a whole, well, 'watered down' is the phrase that comes to mind. Someone brought their side project to the table instead of the sound that made Slipknot adored by so many.<br /><br />Ultimately, only four songs save this CD from being completely unlistenable. The Blister Exists is a great song once you get used to the change. Circle, as much as I hate to admit it, is a great ballad. Ballad and Slipknot just shouldn't be said in the same sentence, it's like saying Britney Spears has an amazing voice, it doesn't sound right. Welcome and Pulse Of The Maggots are the only two songs that bring any amount of the energy executed on the first two releases to us. That's it, four songs out of 14 that are good.<br /><br />My favorite songs are The Blister Exists, Circle, Welcome, and Pulse Of The Maggots. In no way is this the Slipknot I came to love, and I can only hope that if they make another CD that it'll take them back to the days where total disregard for opinions seemed to be what got them off. Changing and growing as a band is great, and it should happen, but this isn't growing as a band, this is giving in to pressure to make a radio ready CD. I hate that this CD even had to be made and it certainly hasn't held any of it's integrity since it was first released. Needless to say, if you like Stone Sour, you'll love Vol. 3.a band, this is giving in to pressure to make a radio ready CD. B00000255F|5.0|It's easy to forget how good this album is or take it for granted. When I first heard it in 1975, I was swept away with Bruce's cinematic approach and intensity. The Phil Spector-like production values and lyrical visions of tough luck kids on  fast cars or motorcycles wanting out of the dreary overcast Jersey landscape, looking across the river to New York, hoping for a better life is poignant. He captures the characters and the moods very well. This is a unifying theme thoughout most blue-collar neighborhoods in America. It was a very romantic view of young America with a mix of doo-wop, hustlers, rock and roll, and West Side Story images. This is without a doubt..ONE OF THE TEN BEST ALBUMS OF ALL TIME! Unfortunately, when you hit 75 home runs with a .450 average for one season, everyone expects the same again and again. In my estimation, I've always been waiting for another Born To Run, but that would be impossible. 1978's Darkness, was a shadow of that. 1984's Born In The USA came close.  It's the Orson Welles syndrome, after Citizen Kane...how can you top that! Well, if Bruce never recorded another note after Born to Run, he would have still made rock history. Every song is a Rolls Royce in production, melody and lyrical values. When you create a masterpiece...what can you do for an encore?

Reavers are in a very basic sense (and probably inspired by) native american scalpers. Anyway, the movie is great and it is a sci-fi movie for the ages.

0930289528|5.0|In an alternate universe England, a vicious, third World War destroyed the country's government, allowing right-wing, Nazi-like dictators to take over and transform it into a fascist police state--a living hell of a place where secret police run the streets and the ones in charge use hidden surveillance to keep watch over everything and everyone at all times. Everything now seems \\"normal\\" and free of any crime, evil or corruption. But there is one man who sees the true ugliness behind everything, a man, a Guy Fawkes mask-clad, cloaked, anarchist revolutionary known only as \\"V,\\" who uses vigilantism and terrorism as \\"message.\\" This \\"V\\" is actually a former prisoner and guinea pig to a dangerous hormone that most likely caused him to lose his mind, from one of the hellish resettlement camps abundant during the war, condemned for his radical, political beliefs. But now he's back, and he has vendetta on the brain. But his violent tactics are only a small part of a theatrical, one-man conspiracy to destroy England fascist government. Along the way, V rescues a young woman, Evey Hammond, who proves she may be of some help to the radical vigilante. <br /> <br />Most likely playing seconds only to \\"Watchmen\\" as Alan Moore's greatest achievement, the master writes his deepest, most personal fears into \\"V for Vendetta\\"--a world without people of different race, sexual orientation, political dissidents, anything that reminds us of diversity. What Moore says in his work is without diversity there is no spiritual growth, and without spiritual growth there is no freedom, and without freedom there is no choice, and without choice there is no real justice. Although \\"Watchmen\\" is regularly regarded as Moore's best work, \\"V for Vendetta\\" deserves as much praise, if not more. In some area's \\"V for Vendetta\\" is actually stronger and scarier than \\"Watchmen,\\" mainly because the main \\"hero\\" uses terrorism to make the world a \\"better\\" place. \\"V for Vendetta\\" is also a more, possibly the most, personal of Moore's writes because of the way he describes his innermost fears--a disturbingly real world where diversity is banned in a Nazi-like England. <br /> <br />What I like best about Moore's works is that he always has some kind of significant point to make. Similar to \\"Watchmen,\\" \\"V for Vendetta\\" is a story based on the \\"how much one COULD do for the world over how much one SHOULD do\\" formula Moore is known for. He does this brilliantly, and V is his most psychologically driven, and interesting character in any of his previous/future works. As a side note, it took me some getting used to Dave Lloyd's gritty, often flat, artwork (especially after Dave Gibbons' much \\"cleaner\\" artistic contribution on \\"Watchmen\\"), but it somehow fits the overall atmosphere and disturbing theme of Moore's dark story. I recommend this book to anyone who likes to think, to anyone with a taste for great, symbolic literature, and to all graphic novel enthusiasts. England prevails!

B0000931QA|5.0|\\"It's ten minutes past curfew, why are you still up?  Hello?  Hell-ooo?  Perhaps you need another shot.  There, that should do it...sweet dreams...you bastard...\\"<br /><br />So it begins...<br /><br />Nearly 20 years after its initial release, Operation Mindcrime truly stands the test of time.  Listening to it again, it's amazing how undated the album sounds.  I'm not speaking only of the musicianship, which shines on its own.  All five members of this incredible band - Geoff Tate and his opera-quality vocals; Chris de Garmo and Michael Wilton's shared guitar stylings; the rock solid bass of Eddie Jackson, and the almost insane drumming of Scott Rockenfield (whom along with Neil Peart, Mike Portnoy, and Terry Bozzio complete the holy quad of great drummers of rock) - are positively sublime.<br /><br />However, it is topically where this album resonates the most.  Eerily prophetic, Mindcrime's bleak vision of a country drunk on religion, sex and powerplays (to borrow from 'Spreading the Disease') is uncomfortably reminiscent of the U.S. situation now.  Nicky is that lost soul many of us could be, looking for hope and love in a world that doesn't seem to believe in it anymore.  Kind of sad how things have progressed steadily worse from the time this album was first released.<br /><br />One of my favourite tracks on this album is Suite Sister Mary, that begins with the ominous rumble of Dr. X who urges our anti-hero, Nicky, \\"kill her, that's all you have to do...\\"  It's a ten-minute magnum opus with vocalist Pamela Moore as the ex-stripper/prostitute/now nun, Sister Mary.  This is a role that not just any female singer could handle, especially because it called for singing duet with one of the greatest metal vocalists in the world and she pulled it off magnificently.  If you saw the concert production of Operation Mindcrime (I did - TWICE!!!), Ms. Moore wasn't using studio tricks either.  She was indeed the real deal.<br /><br />This is the album that actually wound up on the PMRC's 'Hit List' for the infamous line: \\"Educate the masses/Gonna burn the White House down\\".<br /><br />Let's face it though, while 'Eyes of a Stranger' did get some airplay, the entire album was (and is) way too cerebral for the MTV crowd.  For the rest of us who can appreciate artistry and thought-provoking themes in our music, Operation Mindcrime will always be one of the greatest musical works of the modern age.ally wound up on the PMRC's 'Hit List' for the infamous line: \\"Educate the masses/Gonna burn the White House down\\". <br /> <br />Let's face it though, while 'Eyes of a Stranger' did get some airplay, the entire album was (and is) way too cerebral for the MTV crowd. 8389533391|5.0|This is one of the best and most creative films ever made. Totally inventive in concept, the story revolves around an exuberant and romantic Italian man named Guido, who also happens to be Jewish. He sweeps the woman of his dreams,his \\"Principessa\\", off her feet. They marry and have an adorable little boy whom they dearly love. Unfortunately, this all happens during World War II in fascist Italy.<br /><br />Ultimately, Guido and their son are whisked away to a concentration/work camp on their young son's birthday. Meanwhile, his wife and the boy's mother, coming home and expecting to find a birthday celebration in progress, discovers, instead, that the inevitable has occurred. She tracks them down to the train that is taking prisoners to a work camp and, after confirming that they are on board, insists upon boarding the train herself, so that she may remain close to them. They see her board the train and know that she is with them.<br /><br />In order to get his son through this horror as best he can, Guido tells his son that they are involved in a real life game to win a tank, knowing that the boy had wanted a toy tank for his birthday. Talk about a reality survival game! In any case, his son is young enough to fall for it and gets with the program as only the very young can. What follows is a series of inventive scenarios which tells the viewer of the lengths that the father goes in order to keep his son quiet, obedient, entertained, and safe from harm. All along, the father has his son believing in the game and playing to win, to the point that the boy believes that they are actually in first place to win the tank.<br /><br />While this may sound like an odd venue in which to find oneself laughing, that is exactly what the viewer does. At the same time, the film is achingly poignant, and the end is infinitely sad. Guido is played to perfection by comedic star and filmmaker Roberto Benigni, who also directed this masterpiece. His on screen wife and comedic foil is played by his real life main squeeze, Nicoletta Braschi. The son is played with wondrous innocence by the totally adorable Giorgio Cantarini. This is an award caliber film that saw Benigni deservedly capture Oscars for Best Actor and Best Foreign Language Film.<br /><br />All in all, this film will leave the viewer both laughing and crying. Also, the computer animation part of the movie was to much, just didn't look good at all.  Finally, whats the deal with the antigravity everything and the color shifting cloths, Is that in the comic book?  If it is, I appologize, but if it was a movie adaptation, it would have been nice to have a little explanation behind the mechanism of some of these devices, and that would have been solved by actually puting in some real dialog.  I did not rate this a one, because it did have some ok fight scenes, but this is just worth a rental, unless you are a huge fan.
